phrasalVerbs.title: Figure out
examples: I can't figure out how to solve this problem.
I need to figure out what to do next.

phrasalVerbs.title: Do it over
examples: I made a mistake, so I have to do it over.
The project was not good, so I have to do it over.

phrasalVerbs.title: Get Through
examples: I need to get through this work before the deadline.
I got through the book in one day.

phrasalVerbs.title: Get out of one's way
phrasalVerbs.description: To move out of someone's path
examples: I had to get out of his way because he was in a hurry.
I had to get out of the way of the car.

phrasalVerbs.title: Get along with
phrasalVerbs.description: To have a good relationship with someone
examples: I get along with my boss.
I get along with my colleagues.

phrasalVerbs.title: Bring Up
examples: I brought up the issue in the meeting.
I brought up the topic of the project.

phrasalVerbs.title: Call off
examples: The meeting was called off.
The event was called off due to bad weather.

phrasalVerbs.title: Come across
examples: I came across an old friend in the market.
I came across a book that I had been looking for.

phrasalVerbs.title: Come up with
examples: I came up with a new plan for the project.
I came up with a solution to the problem.

phrasalVerbs.title: Wrap Up
examples: Let's wrap up the meeting.
We need to wrap up the project.

phrasalVerbs.title: Put off
examples: The meeting was put off until next week.
The event was put off due to bad weather.

phrasalVerbs.title: Run out of
phrasalVerbs.description: To have no more of something
examples: I ran out of money.
We ran out of time.

phrasalVerbs.title: Take off
examples: I took off my shoes.
He took off his jacket.

phrasalVerbs.title: Turn down
examples: He turned down the job offer.
She turned down the invitation.

phrasalVerbs.title: Turn up
examples: He turned up late for the meeting.
She turned up at the party.

phrasalVerbs.title: Look forward to
phrasalVerbs.description: To be excited about something that will happen
examples: I am looking forward to the weekend.
She is looking forward to the party.

phrasalVerbs.title: Make up
examples: He made up an excuse for being late.
She made up a story about the missing book.

phrasalVerbs.title: Put up with
examples: I can't put up with his behavior anymore.
She put up with the noise from the construction.

phrasalVerbs.title: Set up
examples: He set up a new business.
She set up a charity.

phrasalVerbs.title: Take after
examples: She takes after her mother.
He takes after his father.

phrasalVerbs.title: Get Into
examples: I got into photography.
She got into painting.

phrasalVerbs.title: Get over
phrasalVerbs.description: To recover from an illness or a bad experience
examples: I got over the flu.
She got over the breakup.

phrasalVerbs.title: Go on
examples: The meeting went on for hours.
The party went on until late.

phrasalVerbs.title: Hold on
examples: Hold on a minute, I'll be right back.
Hold on, I need to make a call.

phrasalVerbs.title: Stick to
phrasalVerbs.description: To follow a plan or a decision
examples: I need to stick to my diet.
She stuck to her decision.

phrasalVerbs.title: Stick Around
examples: I'll stick around until you finish.
She stuck around to help.

phrasalVerbs.title: Leave Off
examples: Leave off talking and listen to me.
She left off working and went home.

phrasalVerbs.title: Zone Out
phrasalVerbs.description: To lose concentration or become unaware of what's happening around you.
examples: I totally zoned out during the meeting.
He tends to zone out when he's tired.

phrasalVerbs.title: Pack In
phrasalVerbs.description: To stop doing something or to quit a habit, job, or activity.
examples: She packed in her job to travel the world.
I think it's time to pack in smoking.

phrasalVerbs.title: Run Into
phrasalVerbs.description: To meet someone unexpectedly or to encounter a problem.
examples: I ran into an old friend at the mall.
We ran into some technical issues with the software.

phrasalVerbs.title: Carry Out
phrasalVerbs.description: To perform or complete a task, plan, or order.
examples: The team carried out the experiment successfully.
They carried out a survey across several cities.

phrasalVerbs.title: Straight Out
phrasalVerbs.description: To say something directly and honestly without hesitation.
examples: He told me straight out that he wasn’t interested.
Just tell her straight out how you feel.

phrasalVerbs.title: Pipe Down
phrasalVerbs.description: To stop talking or make less noise.
examples: Hey, pipe down! I'm trying to study.
The teacher asked the students to pipe down.

phrasalVerbs.title: Throw Up
examples: He felt sick and threw up after the ride.
The baby threw up all over the floor.

phrasalVerbs.title: Hold Back
phrasalVerbs.description: To stop yourself from doing something or expressing a feeling.
examples: She held back her tears during the speech.
Don’t hold back—tell him how you really feel.

phrasalVerbs.title: Cheer Up
phrasalVerbs.description: To become happier or make someone feel happier.
examples: Cheer up! Things will get better soon.
I brought you some cake to cheer you up.

phrasalVerbs.title: Chill Out
phrasalVerbs.description: To relax and not get angry or stressed.
examples: You need to chill out and take a break.
We’re just chilling out at home this weekend.

phrasalVerbs.title: Brighten Up
phrasalVerbs.description: To become or make something more cheerful or lively.
examples: The flowers really brighten up the room.
Her smile brightened up my day.
